net.happybrackets.core.control

Class ClassObjectControl

  • java.lang.Object
    • net.happybrackets.core.control.DynamicControlParent
      • net.happybrackets.core.control.ClassObjectControl
  • Direct Known Subclasses:
    ClassObjectControlSender

    public class ClassObjectControl
extends DynamicControlParent
    This class encapsulates the functionality of DynamicControl classes of type ControlType.OBJECT in a simple API. This enables sending of entire classes as a single message.
    For example, you can send x, y and z values a TripleAxisMessage using the setValue(Object)

    All ClassObjectControl objects with the same name and ControlScope will respond to a setValue(Object). Additionally, the Class of the object that we are sending must also be defined. For example: consider two ClassObjectControl with the same ControlScope and name: 
        ClassObjectControl control1 = new ClassObjectControl(this, "Accel", TripleAxisMessage.class);

    ClassObjectControl control2 = new ClassObjectControl(this, "Accel", TripleAxisMessage.class) {
         @Override
        public void valueChanged(Object object_val) {
            TripleAxisMessage control_val = (TripleAxisMessage) object_val;
            System.out.println("x:" + control_val.getX() + " y:" + control_val.getY() +  " z" + control_val.getZ());
        }

    };

    TripleAxisMessage msg = new TripleAxisMessage(0.1f, 0.2f, 0.3f);
    control1.setValue(msg);


    This will cause the control2 to fire the valueChanged(Object) function with the new value, causing x:0.1 y:0.2 z:0.3 to be printed to standard output
    The control can also schedule messages to be sent at a time in the future by adding the time to the message using an absolute time in the setValue(Object, double) function. For example, the message can be scheduled to execute in 1 second as follows:

    control1.setValue (msg, HB.getSchedulerTime() + 1000); The Class type must be defined within the control

    Values cannot be set within HappyBrackets control displays If you do require a handler on the class, use the valueChanged(Object) class

        public java.lang.Object getValue()
        Get the value for the control
        Returns:
        the control value. If unable to be cast bill be a null value

      • valueChanged

        public void valueChanged(java.lang.Object control_val)
        Fired event that occurs when the value for the control has been set. For example: 
             ClassObjectControl control1 = new ClassObjectControl(this, "Accel", TripleAxisMessage.class);

     ClassObjectControl control2 = new ClassObjectControl(this, "Accel", TripleAxisMessage.class) {
         @Override
        public void valueChanged(Object object_val) {
            TripleAxisMessage control_val = (TripleAxisMessage) object_val;
            System.out.println("x:" + control_val.getX() + " y:" + control_val.getY() +  " z" + control_val.getZ());
        }

     };

     TripleAxisMessage msg = new TripleAxisMessage(0.1f, 0.2f, 0.3f);
     control1.setValue(msg);

        This will cause the control2 to fire the valueChanged(Object) function with the new value, causing x:0.1 y:0.2 z:0.3 to be printed to standard output
        Parameters:
        control_val - The class object that has been received. If the value could not be cast, the function will not be called

      • setValue

        public void setValue(java.lang.Object val)
        set the value for the control. This will notify all the listeners with same name and ControlScope. For example: 
             ClassObjectControl control1 = new ClassObjectControl(this, "Accel", TripleAxisMessage.class);

     ClassObjectControl control2 = new ClassObjectControl(this, "Accel", TripleAxisMessage.class) {
         @Override
        public void valueChanged(Object object_val) {
            TripleAxisMessage control_val = (TripleAxisMessage) object_val;
            System.out.println("x:" + control_val.getX() + " y:" + control_val.getY() +  " z" + control_val.getZ());
        }

     };

     TripleAxisMessage msg = new TripleAxisMessage(0.1f, 0.2f, 0.3f);
     control1.setValue(msg);

        This will cause the control2 to fire the valueChanged(Object) function with the new value, causing x:0.1 y:0.2 z:0.3 to be printed to standard output
        Parameters:
        val - the value to set to

      • setValue

        public void setValue(java.lang.Object val,
                     double scheduler_time)
        Identical to the setValue(Object) with the exception that the valueChanged(Object) event will be caused at the HBScheduler scheduled time passed in. For example, the following code will cause the valueChanged(Object) to be fired 1 second in the future: 
             ClassObjectControl control1 = new ClassObjectControl(this, "Accel", TripleAxisMessage.class);
     ClassObjectControl control1 = new ClassObjectControl(this, "Accel", TripleAxisMessage.class);

     ClassObjectControl control2 = new ClassObjectControl(this, "Accel", TripleAxisMessage.class) {
         @Override
        public void valueChanged(Object object_val) {
            TripleAxisMessage control_val = (TripleAxisMessage) object_val;
            System.out.println("x:" + control_val.getX() + " y:" + control_val.getY() +  " z" + control_val.getZ());
        }

     };

     TripleAxisMessage msg = new TripleAxisMessage(0.1f, 0.2f, 0.3f);
     control1.setValue(msg, HB.getSchedulerTime() + 1000);
        Parameters:
        val - the value to set to
        scheduler_time - the scheduler time this is supposed to occur at

      • setControlScope

        public ClassObjectControl setControlScope(ControlScope new_scope)
        Changed the scope that the control has. It will update control map so the correct events will be generated based on its scope
        Overrides:
        setControlScope in class DynamicControlParent
        Parameters:
        new_scope - The new Control Scope
        Returns:
        this object

      • setDisplayType

        public ClassObjectControl setDisplayType(DynamicControl.DISPLAY_TYPE display_type)
        Change how to display object as DynamicControl.DISPLAY_TYPE We must do this in subclass
        Parameters:
        display_type - The new Display Type
        Returns:
        this object
